stem: The nurse reviews the clinical data from 0800 to 1100. Which finding most clearly indicates a therapeutic response to the interventions?

options.text: Increased sputum production with purulent characteristics at 1100 compared to 0800.
Presence of hemoptysis noted in sputum at 1000, absent at 0800.
Decreased coughing episodes and thinning of sputum consistency at 1100 compared to 0800.
Temperature elevation from 38.2°C (100.8°F) at 0800 to 38.5°C (101.3°F) at 1100.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 0800: Productive cough, thick purulent sputum, frequent coughing episodes. Patient reports chest discomfort. 0930: Coughing less frequent after nebulizer treatment. Sputum remains thick and yellow. Patient reports slight improvement in chest discomfort. 1100: Coughing significantly decreased. Sputum thinner and easier to expectorate. Patient reports feeling less congested and more comfortable.

tabs.title: Medications
tabs.content: Rifampin 600mg PO daily, Isoniazid 300mg PO daily, Pyrazinamide 1500mg PO daily, Ethambutol 1200mg PO daily, Albuterol nebulizer PRN

tabs.title: Laboratory Results
tabs.content: Sputum culture positive for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Sensitivity testing pending.

rationale.correctRationale: Decreased coughing and thinning of sputum indicate a therapeutic response to TB treatment and airway management. This suggests the infection is beginning to clear, and the airway is less inflamed.

incorrectRationales.option_1: Increased sputum production, especially with purulent characteristics, suggests worsening infection or ineffective treatment. This is an undesirable outcome.
incorrectRationales.option_2: Hemoptysis (blood in sputum) is a concerning sign that could indicate lung damage or worsening of the TB infection, rather than a therapeutic response.
incorrectRationales.option_4: An increasing temperature indicates a possible worsening of the infection or a lack of response to the current treatment regimen. A decreasing temperature would be a more favorable sign.

rationale.clinicalPearls: Monitoring sputum characteristics (volume, consistency, color) and frequency of coughing are key indicators of treatment effectiveness in tuberculosis. Improvement in these parameters suggests a positive response to therapy. Sputum cultures are essential for diagnosis and monitoring treatment effectiveness.
rationale.questionTrap: Students may be distracted by the temperature change in option 4, but the change is minimal and within normal diurnal variation, whereas sputum changes are direct indicators of the pulmonary infection status. Hemoptysis is always a red flag and never a good sign.
rationale.mnemonic: Evaluate TB therapy response using 'SCOUT': Sputum (thinning), Cough (decreasing), Oxygenation (improving), Temperature (normalizing).
